column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0006] The key to efficiency in treatment and maximum quality in results is a realistic simulation of the treatment process.

#Text=Today's orthodontists have the possibility of taking plaster models of the upper and lower jaw, cutting the model into single tooth models and sticking these tooth models into a wax bed, lining them up in the desired position, the so-called set-up.
#Text=This approach allows for reaching a perfect occlusion without any guessing.
#Text=The next step is to bond a bracket at every tooth model.
#Text=This would tell the orthodontist the geometry of the wire to run through the bracket slots to receive exactly this result.
#Text=The next step involves the transfer of the bracket position to the original malocclusion model.

#Text=To make sure that the brackets will be bonded at exactly this position at the real patient's teeth, small templates for every tooth would have to be fabricated that fit over the bracket and a relevant part of the tooth and allow for reliable placement of the bracket on the patient's teeth.

#Text=To increase efficiency of the bonding process, another option would be to place each single bracket onto a model of the malocclusion and then fabricate one single transfer tray per jaw that covers all brackets and relevant portions of every tooth.
#Text=Using such a transfer tray guarantees a very quick and yet precise bonding using indirect bonding.
#Text=[0007] However, it is obvious that such an approach requires an extreme amount of time and labor and thus is too costly, and this is the reason why it is not practiced widely.
#Text=The normal orthodontist does not fabricate set-ups; he places the brackets directly on the patient's teeth to the best of his knowledge, uses an off-the-shelf wire and hopes for the best.
#Text=There is no way to confirm whether the brackets are placed correctly; and misplacement of the bracket will change the direction and/or magnitude of the forces imparted on the teeth.

#Text=While at the beginning of treatment things generally run well as all teeth start to move at least into the right direction, at the end of treatment a lot of time is lost by adaptations and corrections required due to the fact that the end result has not been properly planned at any point of time.
#Text=For the orthodontist this is still preferable over the lab process described above, as the efforts for the lab process would still exceed the efforts that he has to put in during treatment.
#Text=And the patient has no choice and does not know that treatment time could be significantly reduced if proper planning was done.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 5,431,562 to Andreiko et al. describes a computerized, appliance-driven approach to orthodontics.
#Text=In this method, certain shape information of teeth is acquired.
#Text=A uniplanar target archforrn is calculated from the shape information.
#Text=The shape of customized bracket slots, the bracket base, and the shape of an orthodontic archwire, are calculated in accordance with a mathematically-derived target archform.

#Text=The goal of the Andreiko et al. method is to give more predictability, standardization, and certainty to orthodontics by replacing the human element in orthodontic appliance design with a deterministic, mathematical computation of a target archform and appliance design.

#Text=Hence the '562 patent teaches away from an interactive, computer-based system in which the orthodontist remains fully involved in patient diagnosis, appliance design, and treatment planning and monitoring.
#Text=[0009] More recently, in the late 1990's Align Technologies began offering transparent, removable aligning devices as a new treatment modality in orthodontics.
#Text=In this system, a plaster model of the dentition of the patent is obtained by the orthodontist and shipped to a remote appliance manufacturing center, where it is scanned with a laser.
#Text=A computer model of the dentition in a target situation is generated at the appliance manufacturing center and made available for viewing to the orthodontist over the Internet.
#Text=The orthodontist indicates changes they wish to make to individual tooth positions.
#Text=Later, another virtual model is provided over the Internet and the orthodontist reviews the revised model, and indicates any further changes.
#Text=After several such iterations, the target situation is agreed upon.
#Text=A series of removable aligning devices or shells are manufactured and delivered to the orthodontist.
#Text=The shells, in theory, will move the patient's teeth to the desired or target position.
#Text=Representative patents describing the Align process include U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=Nos. 6,217,325; 6,210,162; and 6,227,850, which are incorporated by reference herein.
#Text=[0010] Other patents addressed to planning treatment for a patient include Doyle, U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 5,879,158, Wu et al., U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 5,338,198 and Snow et al., U.S.
#Text=Pat.
